entry.desc: Bind an event handler to the "dblclick" JavaScript event.

argument.name: eventData
argument.desc: An object containing data that will be passed to the event handler.

argument.name: handler
argument.desc: A function to execute each time the event is triggered.

longdesc.p: The dblclick event is sent to an element when the element is double-clicked. Any HTML element can receive this event. For example, consider the HTML:

To trigger the event manually, call .trigger( "dblclick" ):
After this code executes, (single) clicks on Trigger the handler will also alert the message.
The dblclick event is only triggered after this exact series of events:

ul.li: The mouse button is depressed while the pointer is inside the element.
The mouse button is released while the pointer is inside the element.
The mouse button is depressed again while the pointer is inside the element, within a time window that is system-dependent.
The mouse button is released while the pointer is inside the element.

longdesc.p: It is inadvisable to bind handlers to both the click and dblclick events for the same element. The sequence of events triggered varies from browser to browser, with some receiving two click events before the dblclick and others only one. Double-click sensitivity (maximum time between clicks that is detected as a double click) can vary by operating system and browser, and is often user-configurable.
